articles.headline: Ins and Outs of Calling via the Net
articles.snippet: An unscientific study of Internet calling apps — all available for Android phones and iPhones — discovers strengths and weaknesses in the likes of Google Voice and Fring.
articles.abstract: An unscientific study of Internet calling apps — all available for Android phones and iPhones — discovers strengths and weaknesses in the likes of Google Voice and Fring.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week’s e-mail bag brought a note that echoes the sentiments of many others:

articles.headline: Dissenters Fault Report on Crisis in Finance
articles.snippet: Republicans on the government panel investigating the financial crisis said the inquiry had too domestic a focus.
articles.abstract: Republicans on the government panel investigating the financial crisis said the inquiry had too domestic a focus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The government commission’s account of what caused the 2008 financial crisis offers a broad indictment of regulatory weakness, Wall Street avarice and corporate incompetence. But that narrative is competing with alternative views by the Republicans on the panel, who released their dissenting reports on Wednesday.

articles.headline: A Little Less Drama at NBC
articles.snippet: NBC Universal’s chief executive will try to revive the NBC lineup and end the public discord that was often more interesting than the network’s shows.
articles.abstract: NBC Universal’s chief executive will try to revive the NBC lineup and end the public discord that was often more interesting than the network’s shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Thursday, from Studio 6B in Rockefeller Center, home of “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon,” the NBC anchor Brian Williams will officially introduce the network’s newest boss, Stephen B. Burke, in a closed-circuit presentation to the entire company.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Bill Carter

articles.headline: G.O.P. Splits Over Plans to Cut Defense Budget
articles.snippet: Even as their leaders insist on the need for military cuts, divisions have opened among Republicans about how to chop Pentagon spending that comes to more than a half trillion dollars a year.
articles.abstract: Even as their leaders insist on the need for military cuts, divisions have opened among Republicans about how to chop Pentagon spending that comes to more than a half trillion dollars a year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To hear the Republican leadership tell it, the once-sacred Pentagon budget, protected by the party for generations, is suddenly on the table. But a closer look shows that even as Speaker John A. Boehner and Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, insist on the need for military cuts, divisions have opened among Republicans about whether, and how much, to chop Pentagon spending that comes to more than a half trillion dollars a year.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: A Reservist in a New War, Against Foreclosure
articles.snippet: Deutsche Bank foreclosed on the home of Sgt. James B. Hurley and his wife in violation of a law intended to protect service members from such actions while they are overseas.
articles.abstract: Deutsche Bank foreclosed on the home of Sgt. James B. Hurley and his wife in violation of a law intended to protect service members from such actions while they are overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: While Sgt. James B. Hurley was away at war, he lost a heartbreaking battle at home.

articles.headline: Egyptian Youths Drive the Revolt Against Mubarak
articles.snippet: Hosni Mubarak’s traditional opponents have been displaced by the leaderless tens of thousands of young Egyptians who turned out this week to demand an end to his 30-year rule.
articles.abstract: Hosni Mubarak’s traditional opponents have been displaced by the leaderless tens of thousands of young Egyptians who turned out this week to demand an end to his 30-year rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Egypt’s authoritarian president, Hosni Mubarak, played a clever game with his political opponents.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Michael Slackman

articles.headline: Moody’s to Factor Pension Gaps in States’ Ratings
articles.snippet: The change, which had been ardently resisted by some, may turn the tide in favor of more disclosure in the industry.
articles.abstract: The change, which had been ardently resisted by some, may turn the tide in favor of more disclosure in the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Moody’s Investors Service has begun to recalculate the states’ debt burdens in a way that includes unfunded pensions, something states and others have ardently resisted until now.

articles.headline: Despite Politics, Oil Companies Are Lured by Russian Petroleum
articles.snippet: A deal reached Thursday commits Exxon to spend about $1 billion looking for oil on the Black Sea coast, and holds the promise of sharing in the prize if it is discovered.
articles.abstract: A deal reached Thursday commits Exxon to spend about $1 billion looking for oil on the Black Sea coast, and holds the promise of sharing in the prize if it is discovered.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  Exxon Mobil once was poised to acquire a stake in Russia’s largest private oil company, only to have the deal fall apart when the Kremlin arrested the owner and the company went bankrupt.

articles.headline: Crisis Panel’s Report Parsed Far and Wide
articles.snippet: As Wall Street analysts scoured 1,200 supporting documents that the panel released, complaints arose that the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission did not “reach even a rough consensus.”
articles.abstract: As Wall Street analysts scoured 1,200 supporting documents that the panel released, complaints arose that the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission did not “reach even a rough consensus.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Behind closed doors, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, called it “the worst financial crisis in global history, including the Great Depression.”
